ratings.comment: An extremely easy A course. We only have homework for half of the semester, no mid-terms, only one take-home final, and a final project. Almost everybody got full points on HW and it counts toward 60%. Take-home final exam contains one easy problem and two intermediate problems. The final project is to write a reading report, takes me 10 hr.
Tough grader and bad instructional quality.
If you like crying when you leave your final he is your professor
He is a good professor, although the final exam is very hard.
He is an amazing grader! It is more important to have a good TA on this course. do your research.
Would not recommend. Hard to understand, especially with online lectures. First midterm was fair, but second midterm (online) was unreasonably difficult. Avoid if possible.

Tests were 80% of grade. Not doing great on one test set you back so far and even basically perfect scores on other stuff won't bring you up. He's not a great lecturer, but tried to get better and asking questions and clarifications in class about what he was doing and why helped alot, but all of that changed during online lectures and it was bad.

He cares about the content and if you're learning it but tests you on it in a very unfair way. Wish I could rate his TA's because they don't care about the students at all, especially worse after we went online.

Can't understand what he's trying to say during lectures or in the recorded videos. Exams are strange and difficult. I expect really learning something in this course for the future math courses, but just can't.

Professor Fang seems to be a smart individual, however he does a bad job of explaining tough concepts. His tests were somewhat difficult, but he often seemed to add questions that were unnecessarily difficult and he seemed to flex his knowledge. He made his final proof based as a way to lower students grades. This lead to many people failing

Can be hard to understand, goes quickly in lecture, often doesn't explain concepts well enough, seldom gives a big picture explanation or how it is important overall/connects to other concepts -- would not recommend overall; final exam was ridiculously hard compared to the two midterms and it was not reflective of the entire course content

If you aren't that great at learning math, choose a different lecturer. He tends to go over proofs a lot during lecture, and can be unclear on what topic he is teaching. He has online homework due every Friday, including midterm days and Thanksgiving break. The midterms were easy, but the final was very hard. Learn material before lectures.

Decent professor but lectures can get quite dry sometimes. Class itself is probably easier than 222 mechanics wise. At least he goes through examples in class and the first two midterms weren't that difficult.

I stopped going to class because the lectures just made me more confused, but the tests and quizes are fair. Tests are very short though. If you want to learn from the professor don't take him but if you just want the credit and can learn on your own take him. This might've been his first class so hopefully he'll get better with practice.

He's a decent professor. I appreciate that he gets to the point in lecture and spends time on example problems. What he lacks is an explanation of the concepts behind what he's doing, which makes the class much harder. The overall class structure is pretty decent. This was my first math class at UW Madison so I can't really compare.

I took MATH 234 with Fang in fall 2019. Fang always takes time to answer students questions during lecture and office hours. Fang does not waste too much time with proofs that no one can understand, rather spends in on example problems. The first midterm was easy and the class overall is easier than MATH 222 as long as you try.
